text: I first have to ask about the
inauguration I saw you there at the
inauguration and I was I know how I felt
watching the first Hispanic to to
administer the oath of office to a VP
candidate how did you feel it was
another dreamlike moment when I walked
out with my fellow justices I stood in
the front for a few seconds looking out
at that massive crowd and all I could
think is is this real it it it's
impossible to describe to anyone the in
probability that little Sonya from the
projects in the South Bronx would it
ever experience a moment like that and
you know it was a fantasy reaching the
Supreme Court it's been a fantasy
getting to inaugurate the vice-president
to swear him in and now I got a brag a
little bit because the probably the
thing that I would say was beyond the
fantasy that if you had asked me as a
child could it ever happened I wouldn't
have even thought it was a remotest
possibility being number one on the New
York Times
you'll read in the book how much I
struggle to learn English and how to
write well my background is no different
than any migrant or immigrant who speaks
another language and comes to America
and tries to master both a foreign
language and a foreign culture and so my
life was no different than so many and
you'll read about my experiences in
college and how hard I had to work to be
able to write English well and now to
have people writing a book I reading a
book I authored is extraordinary there
were no lawyers or judges in my life so
I had no one to pattern myself after my
model was a TV lawyer and I hate to say
this with all the kids in the audience
because your parents are gonna hate me
but sometimes TV is a good thing
you know you have a very optimistic view
of life yeah and I think you know you
and I probably share that same spirit of
life is you know half you know the glass
is half-full all the time when you read
the book you'll see your circumstances
growing up whether it was poverty or
juvenile diabetes or your alcoholic
father or your mother it was a it was a
very difficult time to manage as a young
girl and you had a life-threatening
disease and so all of these obstacles
could have left you angry and bitter and
two-tiered you from the path that you
eventually took what how do you account
for that how do you account for that
unfailing optimism and there's a quote
in the book and I just want to say this
is your words you say adversity spurred
me instead of knocking me down and it
sure does knock a lot of people down and
I'm very aware that there are life
circumstances where some people can't
recover and I don't mean to suggest that
everyone has control over that choice
you know there are people who suffer
from depression and I my only advice to
them is go seek help particularly in the
Latino community where help is a
negative where they're shame attached to
asking for help
but I do think that from every failure
in life you have an opportunity to learn
something and if you don't concentrate
on the pain because you accept that pain
is a natural inevitable part of life we
will fail at something and and my book I
detailed some of my failures and I did
it because I felt that if I wasn't
honest about them people would think
that all I had had was a successful life
but none of us do and so part of the
reason that I wrote the book was to give
people hope even when they have failed
and to challenge to try to recognize
that they can use it as a learning

I'm a fourth grade teacher in East LA so

I'm sure we hope will be the next 40

community
because of the last election and not for

night
I get questions from people all the time
about what do I feel about immigration
the immigration laws what do I know you
alright she didn't she was very good
what do I feel about the Second
Amendment debate what do I feel about
affirmative action today most of the
time I say I can't talk about it because
there's a case pending but I always come
back and say why are you asking me are
you asking herself what do you feel
about it do you like it don't you like
it and then the next question what are
you doing to change what you don't like
and so if that's my hope that's what I
think the last election showed me but
it's not enough to go out and vote now
it's important to go and be active in
your communities for change if you don't
like what your school looks like parents
go to your schools and work on improving
them if you don't like what your
neighborhood looks like form a Citizens
Committee and do something about it you
know if you're unhappy with a particular
law whatever it might involve go out and
lobby your local politicians write to
your Congressman send a letter to the
president do what you need to do to make
our voices heard and I don't mean just
Latinos I mean American voices heard
